importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The annual session of the National People’s Congress in March 2026 is expected to officially release the full five-year plan for 2026–2030, marking the culmination of policy discussions initiated during the fourth plenum.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The five-year economic plan (2026–2030) is central to the article, outlining China’s strategic economic direction, growth targets, and technological development goals during this period.

keyTakeAways: China’s fourth plenum, a closed-door meeting of the Chinese Communist Party, will finalize key policies and goals for the next five years (2026–2030).
The meeting occurs amid heightened trade tensions with the U.S., especially due to policies under President Donald Trump, increasing pressure on China’s export strategy and technology policies.
Economic growth is targeted at around 4.8–5%, with a slowdown in July–September 2025 indicating ongoing challenges.
China is prioritizing technological self-sufficiency, particularly in artificial intelligence, and reducing reliance on U.S. advanced computer chips due to export controls.
Major domestic challenges include low consumer confidence, a property sector downturn, and demographic shifts such as an aging population and youth unemployment (16–24 age group: ~19%).

Policy focus includes boosting consumer spending through subsidies for child care, loans, and trade-in programs for appliances and electric vehicles, though progress may be limited by past economic bubbles.
Economists suggest that bolder, structural reforms are needed to overcome overcapacity and stimulate demand, especially in sectors like automotive where price wars are damaging competitiveness.
China’s leadership emphasizes stability, legitimacy, and economic growth as core values, with the ability to deliver sustained growth being key to maintaining political legitimacy.

summaryOfNewsArticle: The fourth plenum of the Chinese Communist Party, set to begin on October 19, 2025, marks a critical moment in shaping China’s economic strategy for 2026–2030. With leadership under Xi Jinping, the meeting aims to finalize policies amid growing trade tensions with the U.S. under President Donald Trump, who has intensified export controls and tariffs. Key economic priorities include achieving 4.8–5% growth, promoting technological self-sufficiency—especially in artificial intelligence and semiconductors—and revitalizing consumer spending through targeted subsidies. However, domestic challenges such as a property sector crisis, low consumer confidence, youth unemployment, and an aging population complicate these goals. Experts suggest that while the current plan follows familiar patterns, bolder reforms may be needed to address structural imbalances. The full five-year plan will be formally unveiled at the National People’s Congress in March 2026.
title: China's Fourth Plenum Prepares 2026–2030 Economic Plan Amid Trade Tensions
